comments.commentBody: Yeah,  let's remember we're playing with house money now.  The Chargers are a well-balanced team whose time is now.  The Chargers are at a level the Jets could be at in a season or two.  San Diego fans are really passionate, a great sports town, so Jack Murphy stadium will rocking and the fans sloshed.  The Jets are cool though; they're loose- we got a chill coach.  Nothing to lose, eye of the tiger,

The question is why Yemen is the new base for extremist movements in the Arabian Peninsula?
The international conference which British Prime Minister Gordon Brown will host later this month on Yemen is on the right track. It will focus on stimulating international support for Yemen’s’ effort in the fight against terrorism, and to gain support for a comprehensive reform. The task has become more difficult because problems are so deep and huge. The attendees are representatives from forty-three nations and should discuss the causes young Yemenis to join extremist militant organizations. They should focus on the factors that make Yemen a new base for these extremist movements and make tribes provide protection for them. These causes and factors are:

1. People are angry at the government for many reasons. There is a gap between the living standard in Yemen and the neighbor Arab Gulf countries; the unemployment rate is more than 37%; half the population is living in poverty; the economy is collapsing without a specific strategy to lift the country out of crises; corrupted justice system; corrupted military and security systems; the absence of security services in many areas across the country; no plan to secure the short supply of water, no alternative plan for the oil revenue which expect to run out in a decade; the concentration of power in the hands of relatives.
2. Tribes live in permanent wars with each other and with authority. Therefore tribesmen are well trained as soldiers and represent a valuable source for recruiters.
3. Weapons trade is everywhere.
4. Yemen is the ancestral home of Osama Bin Laden and some leaders of Al-Qaeda belong to big tribes.
5. Al-Houthi rebels are battling government forces in Saada governorate since 2004. This extremist group gets support from Iran and from Shiite groups across the region such as Hezbollah.
6. Many Yemenis have lived in Saudi Arabia for many years. Most of these people have experienced humiliation with no human rights. This situation has created a fertile ground for terrorist’s recruiters.
7. Many Yemenis in the south were trained ideology by the Soviet Union as militants and special service agents. After the reunification of the north and south in 1990, these experts lost their jobs and interests. Their experiences and expertise are valuable now for terrorist organizations.
8. Even though everybody around the world has seen some of Al-Qaeda leaders in front of the television cameras with tribesmen around them, government is still sensitive about declaring a real war.
9. The opposition groups leading by the Islamic Brotherhood (Islah), the Socialist party and others (Coalition for Reform) are trying to make the situation worse and worse.
10. Separatist campaign in the south with absence of local authority.
11. Corruption and instability which prevent Arab Gulf States and others to invest in Yemen makes the economical crises so huge.
12. The strategic location in the Bab al-Mandab strait and in the south corner of the Gulf countries.

The Chargers have not scored less than 20 points in a game all year. Unlike the Bengals, they have the luxury of throwing away from Revis and still having terrific targets. Sanchez will not only have to play "mistake free", but also make 2 or 3 of touchdown passes. Can he? And if so, can Edwards hang on to them?
My heart says yes.
My head says no.

First of all, Walt, let's remember that Chad served us faithfully, if not (always) well. Secondly, the JETS did pretty well defensively against the Saints; 'twas the offense that lost that game, in particular a certain rookie QB who was still learning the game. And just how good is the Charger defense, anyway?

We can't clone Revis to cover all their receivers, but it can be done. And Nate Kaeding is a damn good kicker, even better than Feely.

Ain't gonna be easy but it can be done. GO JETS!!
I recommend a visit at the Calypso Cabaret. My Family and myself had a lot of fun seeing this perfect Show at the Asia Hotel.
Terrific idea!

I think for a start, to help us make better food decisions, we should restore the laws that require all ingredients be listed on packages.

I'd like to know what "spices" or "natural and artificial flavors" are in there.

I'd also like to know what pesticide residues are there, as well.

At least armed with information, consumers can make wise choices.
It was about time. As a person who tries eating relatively healthy but does not have the time and money to cook from scratch too frequently, this is a welcome change.
This would be a good step in real health reform.

It's about time! Can we not be allowed to add our own measure of salt?
An intersting data point is this: I have noticed that a typical American can of tomato product has 2 or 3 grams of added salt whereas a similar
can of Italian tomatoes has less than 1 gram of added salt.
America has ceded/lost control of its food chain. Agribusiness must
be put in its place. Don't force me to have excess salt!

comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, New York
comments.commentBody: As Mike would know, road salt destroys roads, bridges, tunnels, all vehicles, water table, wells, fields, shoes, carpets - and builds where it collects. When not in solution, it forms dust we breathe, especially in cold weather after the clean up. This is very expensive. Thanks, SBL

Malcolm Gladwell's book Outliers details a study of the city of Roseto where apparently, no one understood the Mayor's healthy living rules but had an almost zero level of heart disease.

We have created a society that thrives on stress and to compensate, we eat.

What we have lost is our ability to control the pace of our lives, rest, and feel safe in a close, personal community. If we ever get that back our health will most likely return but, unlike salt content, that can't be legislated.
Less fat, salt, and sugar in processed foods will reduce our national health care costs by billions.  As these are the cheapest ingredients, expect a huge fight from food processors.

But I thought Bloomberg, himself loves salty foods...

To each his own -- while I commend the effort, I believe that food choices are an individual responsibility...perhaps salt/sodium intake can be decreased for public school lunches and food banks first.
Kudos to NYC for taking a lead in common sense public health measures!

This is certainly needed nation-wide!  As a person with high blood pressure for which I am taking three drugs without conspicuous success, I try to regulate my salt intake, but when eating out, it's impossible.  Recently in a restaurant when the server asked, "How is everything?" I told her the mashed potatoes were too salty for me to eat.  Breezily she suggested, "Next time order the risotto."
That's funny, I thought the body needs salt to function properly...  Perhaps they can apply this effort to road clearing efforts-- last I checked, salt is worse for trees than humans

There was no mention of the worst offender: Potato chips, corn chips etc. There's no way to make a tasty chip without salt! If you're interested in reducing your sodium intake, skip the chip! It's a high calorie, high salt, no nutrient 'food'. Why eat it?
While we're at it, let's stop using it on the roads too.  It poisons our water supply, eats through pavement and sidewalks, rust our cars, kills trees and god only knows what else.

I am really thankful that someone is finally leading the fight in reforming the American food supply.  I feel we as Americans are being "poisoned" by the additives and non-natural substances we allow to be added to our foods.  Our food has too much salt and too much sugar added to it.  I am fine with processed/convenience foods as long as they are made in the most healthy, natural manner possible.  Right now Big Food in the US tries to do everything at the lowest cost possible at the cost of our health.  Thankfully the Bloomberg administration is stepping up to tackle this, which apparently cannot be done in Washington due to Big Food's powerful lobbying efforts.  I am happy the Bloomberg administration is trying to do something to benefit citizens and their right to healthy food.

Please! Leave us alone! You've taken away our jobs, our retirement money, our homes, our pleasures. Let us have our salt, our tobacco, our cholesterol, our booze, whatever it is. Stop trying to run our lives and save us from ourselves!

In general, this is probably a good effort. High sodium diets contribute to heart disease. However, it's important to note the potential trade-off between foods that are desirable to consumers between salt and fat: anyone who cooks knows that a little extra salt makes lighter meals taste more palatable (to a point). Again, I don't think this is a big deal with prepared snacks or restaurant food, but it's something to keep in mind at the margins.

I have a friend who's switched to a low-salt diet, and he and I were brainstorming ways he could eat food he likes and still enjoy it, with less salt. One thing we came up with was that MSG contains a lot less sodium than a comparable amount of salt. A little MSG also goes a long way, so barring any food allergies, that could be a good alternative for some individuals, or some foods, to high salt intake. (In early 2008, sometime, the New York Times food columnist wrote an article about how the negative health arguments regarding MSG, other than potential allergies, are misguided. I don't remember all of them exactly, but I remember it being fairly convincing.)

--I actually looked up potassium glutamate for my friend, thinking that he might further cut some of his sodium intake from MSG with that. I could only find it from industrial suppliers, however. In any event, glutamic acid--what you're really tasting that's not just salt in MSG--in in soy sauce and seaweed, so feasibly that could be used with less salt to make otherwise-bland foods exciting.
Here's an alternate suggestion, oh many levels of overweening government -- stop regulating our lives to death and LEAVE US ALONE!

OK, this is going too far. The Bloomberg administration should go away and mind its own business taking care of New York City, not go on a nationwide prohibitionist campaign against salt.

Personally, I like salt. I cook with basic ingredients -- fresh vegetables and meats -- and control the amount of salt I use to my taste and to what I consider healthy. I am aware of the health issues. If you don't like salt or think it's unhealthly, don't use it! And packaged foods already are labeled with their sodium content. Read the labels before you buy them. There is a hazy continuum between well-meaning encouragement to coersion to opression. We've gone down that road as a nation before with other things. Treat us like adults. Let us decide for ourselves with the informed choices we already have available rather than telling the rest of us how to eat and live.

My personal goals for salt in packaged foods are 2 milligrams of salt per gram of food for low-salt, 4 - 5 milligrams of salt per gram of food for medium salt, everything else is high salt.

In looking for ways to deal with flavor, I've found other flavors such as lemon or lime to be useful in, for example, low-salt tomato drinks. I choose my bread for its low-salt content, usually 100 - 115 milligrams of salt per slice. I note that bread products with fruit in them (raisin bread, raisin or blueberry bagels) contain less salt.

I welcome the effect of New York's program on foods available elsewhere, It would be nice to see more choice in reduced-salt foods, and perhaps fewer will be withdrawn from grocery shelves. I hope the competition also cuts the price of low-salt soups, some of which are several dollars per can.

Learn to use the low-salt foods so there will be room in your diet for potato chips.
